ygData.subject: RE: [cantera] Flame validation
ygData.msgSnippet: I think the current version of Cantera uses 1st-order backward (upwind) differencing for the convective terms in the species and energy equations. Reading

I think the current version of Cantera uses 1st-order backward (upwind)

differencing for the convective terms in the species and energy
equations.

Reading through the documentation of the HCT
(http://www-cms.llnl.gov/combustion/combustion_home.html)
code there seem to be substantial differences from the method by which
Cantera (and probably Chemkin) 
calculates flames.   It would interesting to know which part of the HCT
methodology accounts for the robustness:

1) finite volume vs. finite difference
2) fully compressible vs. isobaric
3) eulerian/lagrangian vs. eulearian
4) unsteady vs. steady (w/ time-stepping)

I would think most of the robustness of HCT comes from using the fully
compressible formulation (2)
which provides time dependent terms for density and the axial velocity.
 This would improve the diagonal 
dominance of the system Jacobian and improve the convergence of the
Newton iterations.  There would
also seemed be some benefit of a looser coupling of density and
temperature in the ideal gas equation by
allowing the pressure to vary.

Dave H.

>>> westbrook1@... 8/2/2004 11:34:37 AM >>>
To anyone interested,

We have had a lot of involvement with very large reaction mechanisms, 
and we have found that Chemkin does not perform well for our large 
mechanisms.  In cases where Chemkin cannot converge on an initial 
flame model, we can run the same flame on our own code, HCT, and then 
use that solution to get within the "radius of convergence" of the 
solution for Chemkin.  Our HCT code "never fails to converge", which 
is largely due to its fairly primitive first-order, backward 
difference solution technique.  I suggest for people running either 
Cantera or Chemkin, if you can force either to run using this 
solution technique, you can probably get an answer, then refine the 
differencing in subsequent runs that start from the first set of 
solutions.  The first-order, backward differencing is supposed to be 
unconditionally stable if done properly, and our experience is that 
it works, even if you don't much like the solution.   I don't know if 
you can force this in Cantera, but it might be a valuable feature.

Charlie Westbrook




>Dave,
>
>I have 50 or so converged laminar flame cases in Chemkin II Premix,
most for
>the experiments from the literature. Fuels are from methane to
benzene,
>low-p to atmospheric, simulated with a few detailed kinetic models
from the
>literature and with two of my own, ranging from 100 to 1200 reactions.
(200
>or so runs in total). All the flames have temperature profile from
the
>experiment. That's kind of a lot for the e-mail attachment.
>
>For about a third of those runs I have cantera solution as well, all
with
>multicomponent diffusion. Differences between cantera and CK Premix
>solutions are  in most cases negligible. In few cases I examined in
detail,
>the differences originate from your improvenments in diffusion
formulation.
>
>To my experience, Cantera (my Python premixed script) handles many a
case on
>which CK Premix gives up, but I have a handfull of cases that neither
code
>could find a solution for.
>
>Which address would you like the stuff sent to? I e-mailed you one of
my
>premixed Python/Cantera scripts to 'dgoodwin@...' on May 11,
but I
>never heard back from you...
>
>Sincerely,
>             Zoran
>
>
>
>I am interested in doing some validation tests of the flame models in
>Cantera, and would like to ask the assistance of anyone who routinely
>runs flame simulations with the Chemkin version 2 codes PREMIX and/or
>OPPDIFF.  What I am looking for are any converged, resolved flame
>solutions from Chemkin 2, including:
>
>1) PREMIX or OPPDIFF input files
>2) reaction mechanism and thermo data files in Chemkin format
>3) computed species and temperature profiles in some text file format
>
>I am particularly interested in non-trivial flames with large
>mechanisms or at atmospheric pressure or above (but any flame is
>useful).  I would also like to have examples both with
mixture-averaged
>and multicomponent diffusion.  If you have this information for some
>flame or flames, please send me a tar or zip file with the files
listed
>above.  I will take this information, generate the corresponding
>Cantera input files + python script, and compare the computed
profiles
>(unless you want to do that too...).  I would plan on then sending
back
>to you the Cantera files, so that you could run a Cantera vs. Chemkin
2
>timing comparison on the same machine.
>
>Based on previous comparisons of thermo properties, transport
>properties, and kinetic rates, I fully expect excellent agreement in
>the steady-state flame profiles, with substantial improvement in
>performance.  But a head-to-head flame comparison would be very
>interesting, and would provide assurance to users converting from the
>Chemkin 2 codes that Cantera produces the same output, given the same
>input.
>
>This will be most useful if we can get at least several flames from
>different groups, running on different machines, etc.
>If you have been wanting to contribute to the development of Cantera
>and its acceptance by the combustion community, but aren't an expert
in
>C++/Python, etc., here's a good opportunity to do so!
>
>Dave
